DataElement.preferredName: Keratinizing Squamous Cell Carcinoma Present Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Term relates to cell type describing degree of squamous differentiation.  Keratinizing tumors have at least one well formed keratin pearl. All other patters are non-keratinizing.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Keratinizing Squamous Cell Carcinoma Present Indicator
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: __A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities._Squamous cell carcinomas with morphologically prominent production of keratin._Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time._An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant squamous cell that does not produce keratin.

Concepts.definition: A malignant squamous cell that does not produce keratin.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated concept with current NCIt term/definition. mc 12/14/17
